Award.AwardTitle: High time resolution astrophysics on the 10m SALT facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an observational program that will use a new high-cadence photon-counting device built by Dr. Welsh's group and now installed at the South African Large Telescope (SALT). The instrument is able to detect the time of arriving photons to microsecond accuracy, and will also detect their positions precisely. The research team plans to study the optical emission properties of millisecond pulsars and X-ray transients, stellar occultations by exoplanets and Kuiper Belt objects, and the eclipse behavior of magnetic cataclysmic variable star systems.

The technology used in this device is important in other fields of scientific study, such as for fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy of single molecules and macromolecules living in cell tissue. The use of this device also requires the development of ultrafast electronic processors. Finally, the instrument will be made available to the astronomical community as a facility instrument at SALT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our view of the Universe at visible wavelengths is dominated by images recorded by (charge-coupled device) detectors that accumulate the emitted photons to produce an image. However all information on how the emitted radiation behaves on time scales less than the integratyion time is lost. The Berkeley Visible Imaging Tube (BVIT) records emitted light on time-scales of less than 1/1000th of a second, thus problng a new window in astronomy.

The BVIT instrument is attached to the 10m Southern African Large Telescope and over the past 3 years has recorded the behavior of  emission from several types of astronomical objects such as flare stars, X-ray binary systems, dwarf novae and pulsating white dwarf stars. These objects all "flicker" on time-scales very much less than 1/1000th of a second, thus revealing a new probe into the physics of stellar emission.

The BVIT instrument was assembled and tested by several undergraduate students at UC Berkeley working on the Undergraduate Research Apprentice Program (URAP). The astronomical data collected by BVIT was also reduced by students working on the URAP program.

The BVIT is now a general-user instrument mounted on the 10m SALT telescope such that other astronomers from all over the world can have access to an instrument that can probe optical emission from a variety of astronomical objects on small time-scales.
